div.ab: These and suchlike are known as the Emotions.

3. Aristides of Thebes first began to express
these things (which the Greeks called Ethe)
in color, seeking to pick in the garden of Art
beautiful new Flowers which smell lovely;
About his wounded wife and her sickness,
And the growth of his renown,
We will soon attend to this subject.
right-middleAristides, the first to depict the Emotions.

4. These emotions are not as ready or easy
to express as they are declared,
first with the parts of the face,
ten or more different views,
as, one forehead, two eyes, and above them
two eyebrows, and beneath them
two cheeks, and in between, nose and chin
and two-lipped mouth, and what is inside.
right-middleThe parts of the face with which the emotions are expressed.

5. Here the Painter must pay tireless attention
to examining the natural essence,
in order to arrange these parts
in relation to one another, so that they reveal
the things that move the heart,
to perform them with the bodyâ€™s gestures:
Everything that the emotions can bring about,
Nature reveals more than one can describe.

6. Yet it would be improper for us to deviate from
some ways, rules and orders
in order to depict these things well,
so that all our characters play
according to the Histrionic Art, and perform
such gestures as would
appear on a Stage, be it in Comedy
with joy, or in sorrowful Tragedy.

7. Now let us first in our work
build a portrayal of the emotion of Love
between Men and Women according to our kind,
with an affectionate smiling gaze,
with embracing, and encircling arms,
and heads inclining toward
one another as if overflowing with Love,
with rights hands clasped.
right-middleOn portraying the emotion of Love.

8. Also between lovers the greatness of Love
can be difficult to feign, yet easy to betray,
through painful shame and exposure of the heart,
spoiling the face with a rosy redness.
And here we wish to add the Example,
(to confirm and fulfill this argument)
right-middleAn example of a History of Antiochus and his Stepmother Stratonice.
